basics.name: Stephen Schor
basics.label: Web Application Programmer
basics.summary: Competent user of popular web frameworks and adjacent technologies. I'm happy if you look at my source and ask "That's it?". This is a cusory overview of my experience. For more information see my personal site, github, and rubygems accounts.

work.summary: Creating and maintaining applications that help archivists describe digitized archival material and make material available to the public on the web.
highlights: Writing maintainable and idiomatic Ruby, & Javascript applications
Shepherded test coverage from 0 to +30% in 5 months.
Limited rights protected video assets by IP address using AWS Cloudfront.
Automated video transcoding for turning working copies into high, web quality video.
Led migrating from Oracle to PostgresSQL.

work.summary: Maintain and build web application and services capable of servicing thousands of requests per second.
highlights: Working in Node.js, Ruby, Golang to strike the best balance between maintainability and performance.
Sharing DevOps responsibilities with a team of fellow highly skilled, handsome developers.

work.summary: Create and maintain technically and organizationally scalable applications for startups and goliaths.
highlights: Creating web applications that can be extended quickly.
Not carrying a balance of technical debt.
Dictating technical infrastructure. Everything from hosting to application server.
Evaluating and implementing libraries for use in Ruby on Rails applications.
Formal and informal training of developers on Ruby best idioms and practices.
Evaluating and implementing libraries for use in Ruby on Rails applications.
Formal and informal training of developers on Ruby best idioms and practices.

work.summary: Automated QA of web applications and aiding our technology's integration on client's applications
highlights: Complex breadth testing of struts-based web application and the JavaScript files it generates.
Creating Ruby driven web automation tests to save 40 man/hours per week.
Creating reusable performance tests for web applications.
Developing Java desktop application to save internal users to 20 hours/ week.
